spanishExample: ¿Adónde va tu padre? ¡Di algo!
englishTranslation: Where is your father going? Say something!

spanishExample: Decía cosas así cuando estaba aquí con nosotros.
englishTranslation: She used to say things like that when she was here with us (m).
vocabIncluded: así: adverb meaning "this way", "that way", "like this", "like that"
decía: "was saying", "he/she/it was saying" (Decir, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Decía que quiero ir, ¿tú qué dices?
englishTranslation: I was saying that I want to go, what do you say?
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
decía: "was saying", "I was saying" (Decir, imperfect, 1st person)

spanishExample: Dicen eso porque están en tu contra.
englishTranslation: They say that because they are opposed to you.

spanishExample: Dijeron que van hacia el lugar donde está tu hermana.
englishTranslation: They said that they are going toward the place where your sister is.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Dijo la verdad, o sea, que había ido a la fiesta sin ella.
englishTranslation: He told the truth, that is, that he had gone to the party without her.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
había: "had", "he/she/it had" before a participle (Haber, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Dile la verdad.
englishTranslation: Tell her the truth.

spanishExample: Dime lo que quieres que digan.
englishTranslation: Tell me what you want them to say.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Fuimos desde ese lugar porque teníamos que decirle eso al niño.
englishTranslation: We went from that place because we had to say that to the boy.
vocabIncluded: al: "to the" before a masculine noun
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: La chica no nos ha dicho nada.
englishTranslation: The girl hasn’t told us anything.
vocabIncluded: ha: "has", "he/she/it has" before a participle (Haber, present, 3rd person)
nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")

spanishExample: La familia le dirá eso a la niña.
englishTranslation: The family will say that to the girl.
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
dirá: "will say", "he/she/it will say" (Decir, future, 3rd person)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Le dije a mi padre: “¡tienes que decirme eso!”
englishTranslation: I told my father: “you have to tell me that!”
vocabIncluded: a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Les dijimos lo que nos dijiste esa noche.
englishTranslation: We told them what you told us that night.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
les: "them" as an indirect object ("to them", "for them")
nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")

spanishExample: Mi esposa dice que lo que está bajo esa cosa es tuyo.
englishTranslation: My wife says that what is under that thing is yours.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Mi esposo tiene que decirte la verdad.
englishTranslation: My husband has to tell you the truth.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Mi hermana dice que está sobre la otra cosa.
englishTranslation: My sister says that it’s above the other thing.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Podemos decir que hiciste eso hace años.
englishTranslation: We can say that you did that years ago.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Que yo sepa, mi madre no quiere que le diga nada a mi padre.
englishTranslation: As far as I know, my mother doesn't want me to tell anything to my father.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")
que yo sepa: "as far as I know" (idiom)

spanishExample: Quiere que le digamos que estamos en su contra.
englishTranslation: He wants us to tell him that we’re opposed to him.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Siempre le decimos a nuestro hijo que puede hacer lo que quiera.
englishTranslation: We always tell our son that he can do whatever he wants.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
le: "her/him" as an indirect object ("to her/him", "for her/him")

spanishExample: Siempre se lo digo todo a mi familia, pero ahora no diré nada.
englishTranslation: I always tell it all to my family, but now I won’t say anything.
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
a, used in a "redundant indirect object", e.g. le hice un favor a la chica
diré: "will say", "I will say" (Decir, future, 1st person)

spanishExample: Su hijo está donde siempre está.
englishTranslation: Her son is where he always is.

spanishExample: Te decimos desde ya que no vamos a poder ir.
englishTranslation: We’re telling you in advance that we aren’t going to be able to go.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
desde ya: "as of now", "from this moment on" (idiom)
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")

spanishExample: Te estamos diciendo todo, sobre todo lo que querías saber.
englishTranslation: We’re telling you everything, especially what you wanted to know.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
te: "you" as an indirect object ("to you", "for you")

spanishExample: Tu hermano lo hará cuando se lo digas.
englishTranslation: Your brother will do it when you say it to him.
vocabIncluded: "se" to mean "le" or "les", as in "se lo" or "se la"
hará: "will do/make", "he/she/it will do/make" (Hacer, future, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Vamos a poder hacerlo cuando nuestra hermana nos diga eso.
englishTranslation: We’re going to be able to do it when our sister tells us that.
vocabIncluded: nos: "us" as an indirect object ("to us", "for us")
using Ir and "a" to put verbs in the future (e.g. "voy a ser")
